courses.description: CHEM1070 is an introductory chemistry course for students with good background of HKDSE chemistry. It includes the study of atomic structure, bonding, periodic trends in physical properties, molecular geometry, stoichiometry, states of matter, thermodynamics, chemical equilibrium, acid/base chemistry, electrochemistry and kinetics. The course is suitable for potential majors in chemistry and other physical sciences.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will understand the basic structures of atoms and simple molecules.

2. Students will be able to rationalize relative positions in the Periodic table, structures of molecules and the chemical properties of molecules.

3. Students will be able to calculate the heat released and absorbed during chemical reactions, related thermodynamic quantities to molecular properties and reactions, predict the equilibrium constant of chemical and phase transfer processes, calculate the solubility of compounds.

4. Students will appreciate the importance of chemistry in real life.

5. Students will realize that chemistry is an open-ended learning experience. They will want to continue learning throughout their lives.

7. Students will be more literate in science. They will develop a comfortable knowledge of science so that they can disseminate science (or pseudo-science) related news articles and/or sales pitches, instead of being intimidated or easily sold.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Matter and Measurement

2. Atoms, Molecules and Ions

3. Basic Concepts of Chemical Bonding

4. Reaction Stoichiometry

5. Reactions in Aqueous Solution

6. Electronic Structure of Atoms

7. Periodic Properties of the Elements

8. Molecular Geometry and Bonding Theories

9. Gases, Liquids, Solids and Modern Materials

10. Thermochemistry and Chemical Thermodynamics

11. Chemical Equilibrium

12. Electrochemistry

13. Chemical kinetics
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- A course questionnaire answered by every student after finishing all the lectures

- Reflections from teachers of courses:

- Feedback from informal conversation and correspondence with students after class
courses.recommended_readings:
1. “Chemistry, the Central Science”, by T.L. Brown, H. E. LeMay, B. E. Bursten, C. J. Murphy, P. M. Woodward; 13rd ed. 2014.

2. “Chemistry for Changing Times”, 12th Ed., John W. Hill and Doris K. Kolb, Prentice-Hall (2009).

courses.description: CHEM1072 is intended to introduce students to the study of chemistry by building concepts and skills related to investigating the structure and nature of matter, and its potential for change. This course is designed for science and engineering students with no or little background in chemistry. The student will learn basic characteristics of matter, atomic structure and bonding, the principles of chemical nomenclature and stoichiometry, fundamental energy concepts, equilibrium, acid and base, and a brief introduction to organic chemistry and biochemistry. This course will help students to prepare themselves for further study of the general chemistry including CHEM1070 and CHEM1280.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CHEM1070. This course is suitable for students with no DSE Chemistry or with HKDSE Combined Science with Chemistry Component.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will understand the basic properties of matters.

2. Students will understand the structures of atoms, chemical bonding, and some simple molecules.

3. Students will understand the concepts in writing and balancing chemical equations.

4. Students will be able to rationalize relative positions in the Periodic table and structures of molecules.

5. Students will be able to calculate the heat released and absorbed during chemical reactions, predict the equilibrium constant of chemical processes, and calculate pH of aqueous solutions.

6. Students will appreciate the importance of chemistry in real life.

7. Students will be more literate in science. They will develop a knowledge in science so that they can disseminate science (or pseudo-science) related news articles.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture 1 Matter and Measurement

Lecture 2 Atoms, Molecules and Ions

Lecture 3 Electronic structures of Atoms

Lecture 4 Periodic properties of the elements

Lecture 5 Stoichiometry of chemical reactions

Lecture 6 Chemical bonding

Lecture 7 Molecular geometry and bonding theories

Lecture 8 Chemical kinetics

Lecture 9 Chemical equilibrium

Lecture 10 Acid-base equilibria

Lecture 11 Chemical thermodynamics

Lecture 12 The chemistry of Life

courses.description: This course provides an overview of organic functional groups that constitute biomolecules. Under themes of common interests and practical importance, this course will provide students with basic principles of organic chemistry to understand the formation, structures and chemical properties of biomolecules. Selected fundamental concepts in chemical bonding and stereochemistry relevant to biomolecules will be highlighted.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CHEM2200.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

• Recognize the molecular structures of common organic compounds.

• Apply the basic concepts of organic chemistry to explain the mechanism for essential chemical reactions of common organic functional groups.

• Identify the structures of biomolecules, understand their essential chemical reactions and explain certain biological functions of biomolecules based on the molecular structures.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

2. Basic Building Blocks for Life: Covalent Bonding and Functional Groups

3. Compounds of Life

courses.description: The transition between high school and university presents new challenges for the students of chemistry. This course reviews the basic concepts of physical chemistry introduced in CHEM1070 and provides the foundations of three mandatory physical chemistry courses in the latter years of the chemistry curriculum. In particular, special topics in thermodynamics, atom structure, quantum chemistry, and chemical kinetics are discussed. Problem-solving skills are introduced to help bridge the gap in the upper-level physical chemistry courses for chemistry majors.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to have a better understanding of key concepts of the principal topics in undergraduate physical chemistry: thermodynamic, kinetics and quantum mechanics. Students will also acquire different problem-solving skills to succeed in the upper physical chemistry courses.
courses.course_syllabus: The transition between high school and university presents new challenges for the students of chemistry. This course reviews the basic concepts of physical chemistry introduced in CHEM1070 and provides the foundations of three mandatory physical chemistry courses in the latter years of the chemistry curriculum. In particular, special topics in thermodynamics, atom structure, quantum chemistry, and chemical kinetics are discussed.

courses.description: This is primarily for students in engineering faculty requiring a one-semester introductory in general chemistry at a fundamental level. It includes the study of atomic structure, bonding, periodic trends in physical properties, molecular geometry, stoichiometry, states of matter, thermodynamics, chemical equilibrium, acid/base chemistry, electrochemistry and kinetics.

After completing this course, students should be able to:

• Incorporate connections between Chemistry and Engineering

• Understand some basic concepts of chemistry in areas related to engineering science such as nuclear chemistry,

chemical equilibrium, thermodynamics, materials, oxidation and reduction, chemical kinetics, electrochemistry and etc.

• Develop problem solving skills in Chemistry and Engineering

courses.description: This course consists of laboratory class, which covers basic techniques and training in experimental chemistry. Students have chances to build experimental apparatus such as polarimeter, fluorometer, and spectroscope. The basic principles of chemistry are also illustrated through experiments. A number of areas related to daily life are also covered, such as polymer, skin care products, analysis of drug content, LED lighting, water purification and analysis, heat pad, and UV test. courses.feedback_evaluation:
* **Course Evaluation Survey (for Laboratory Courses) – Conducted under Science of Faculty**

* *​**Conducted at the end of the course in the form of a questionnaire completed by students, to evaluate the effectiveness of the course.

* **Teaching Performance of Instructors and Demonstrators – Conducted under Department of Chemistry**

Conducted at the end of the course in the form of a questionnaire completed by students, to evaluate the teaching performance of the instructors and demonstrators.

* **Qualitative Feedbacks from Students**

Feedbacks are collected from students informally about their opinions on the course. The feedbacks are collected through the interactions between students and the instructor during the class sessions.

* **Qualitative Feedbacks from Demonstrators**

Feedbacks are collected from the lab demonstrators about their suggestions/comments on the course. Meetings between demonstrators and the instructor are held to collect and discuss the feedbacks given by the demonstrators.

* **Instructor’s reflection**

The course materials/organization are regularly amended/adjusted with reference to:
- Students’ feedbacks (qualitative and quantitative feedbacks)
- Demonstrators’ feedbacks (qualitative feedbacks)
- The learning needs of the students (designed/addressed by the course teacher/instructor)
- Students’ performance in the course (qualitative – quality of their acquired skills and the laboratory reports
submitted; quantitatively – the actual marks obtained by the students)
- Peers’ comments (teaching staff of related fields in the Department)
courses.required_readings: The laboratory manual provided for this course and references cited therein.

courses.description: This course teaches primary spectroscopic techniques used commonly for structure elucidation of organic compounds. It includes: ultraviolet-visible spectrometry, infrared spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, 1H and 13C nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, brief introduction of multinuclear NMR.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge outcomes:
1. Basic concepts and structures of organic compounds.
2. Basic principles of spectroscopic methods including UV-Vis, IR, mass spectrometry and NMR.
3. Techniques for analyzing and interpretation of IR, MS and NMR spectra
4. Application of spectroscopy in chemical analysis and structure elucidation.
Skills Outcomes (Generic Skills)
1. Written and oral communication skills
2. Analytical skills and critical thinking for problem-solving
3. Ability to design scientific experiments to test formulated hypotheses and draw appropriate conclusions by drawing upon
good analytical, research and technical skills.
4. Information retrieval skills through library and internet
Skills Outcomes (Professional Skills)
1. Competence in using computer software to draw chemical structures and reaction schemes.
2. Ability to view chemical structures in 3-D perspectives.
3. Ability to conduct literature reviews / experimental works and write scientific reports.
Attitude / Value Outcomes
1. Desire for carrying out scientific investigation.
2. Awareness on the latest developments and advancements in chemistry and related areas
3. Awareness of the impact of chemistry in social, industrial, environmental and technological contexts.
courses.course_syllabus: ultraviolet-visible spectrometry, infrared spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, 1H and 13C nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, brief introduction of multinuclear NMR.

courses.description: This course covers the fundamental aspects of organic chemistry that are essential to the understanding of the more advanced topics of modern organic chemistry in the senior years. The various chemical bonds commonly encountered in organic chemistry, together with a basic understanding of their chemical reactivity, will be given. In addition, the different classes of organic functional groups will be presented, with a strong focus on their structural aspect, relative reactivity and chemical reaction mechanism.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. The students will learn the fundamental concepts of bonding theories in organic chemistry.
2. The students will acquire the knowledge of organic structures, chemical reactivity and key mechanistic concepts.
3. The students will have a good understanding of the chemistry of key organic functional groups.

In addition, the different classes of organic functional groups will be presented, with a strong focus on their structural aspect, relative reactivity and chemical reaction mechanism.

courses.description: This course builds on fundamental concepts in thermodynamics. Topics covered include state equations of ideal and real gases, the first law of thermodynamics, heat, work and thermochemistry. This course also contains a discussion of the second and third laws, entropy and spontaneous reactions, Gibbs free and equilibria, phase diagrams for one and two component systems, chemical equilibria, and solutions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will have some basic understanding of thermodynamic laws and understand various concepts, particularly entropy and free energy.
2. Students will be able to explain thermodynamic laws, variables and functions and their practical significance.
3. Students will be able to derive important thermodynamic relations and perform numerical calculations of thermodynamic variables.
4. Students will be able to apply thermodynamic principles to analyze practical problems.
5. This will be the first course for students to see how scientific laws and mathematical equations can be developed on the basis of experimental results.
courses.course_syllabus: This course builds on fundamental concepts in thermodynamics. Topics covered include state equations of ideal and real gases, the first law of thermodynamics, heat, work and thermochemistry. This course also contains a discussion of the second and third laws, entropy and spontaneous reactions, Gibbs free and equilibria, phase diagrams for one and two component systems, chemical equilibria, and solutions.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Chemistry of Life
courses.description: (UGEB2380 is double-coded with CHEM2382.)  This course aims to introduce the roles of chemistry in different stages of our life. 'Topics include: 1. basic chemical knowledge related to life science; 2. origin of life - essential elements. water, and proteins; 3. growing up - food. nutrients, and hormones; 4. medication: chemicals against diseases; 5. messing up - narcotics, some stimulant drugs, and hallucinogens ( e g heroin. ketamine, and ecstasy); 6. ageing; 7. the mystery of heredity - nucleic acids and the Double Helix.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students taking this course will learn some basic chemical concepts and knowledge related to life science. They will also understand the role of chemistry in various stages of our life.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1

Introduction I

Some basic concepts in chemistry will be introduced: What is chemistry? Atomic structures, isotopes, molecules and chemical bonding, physical and chemical properties of matters, physical and chemical changes.

Week 2

Introduction II

Oxidation and reduction reactions, acids and bases, the Periodic Table, and a brief introduction to organic chemistry.

Week 3

Origin of Life I

The essential elements and their importance to organisms water and its properties. amino acids and peptides, structures and properties of' proteins, hair-waving and the mad cow disease.

Week 4

Origin ofLife II

An overview on the chemistry of enzymes and the concept of stereochemistry (chirality) will he introduced

Week 5

Growing-Up I

The chemical and biochemical aspects of nutrition will be discussed. An overview on carbohydrates and lipids.

Week 6

Growing-Up II

An overview on vitamins. Hormones - chemical messengers in our body.

Week 7

Mid-term examination

Week 8

Medication I -Chemicals against diseases

Analgesic, antibiotics and anti-viral drugs. The development of some common medicine such asaspirin and acetaminophen will be introduced. Moreover, the chemistry of antibiotics and anaesthetics will also be described.

Week 9

Medication II -Chemicals against AIDS

The immune system. How far can we knock down HIV? AZT and the Cocktail Treatment.

Week 10

Messing Up-Some stimulant drugs

Caffeine and nicotine as common stimulants. Cocaine, amphetamine, and ecstasy as potent stimulant drugs.

Week 11

Messing Up-Narcotics and Hallucinogens

Narcotics - the three opium alkaloids: morphine, codeine, and heroin. Hallucinogens - cannabis. lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), and ketamine.

Week 12

Ageing

What causes ageing? The secrets of ageing will be revealed from a molecular point of view.

Week 13

The mystery of heredity

A walk through the chemistry of nucleic acids and the Double Helix,

Week 14

Nucleic acids and genetics

The mystery behind genetic coding. Biosynthesis of proteins. Genetic diseases.

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with some fundamental concepts in analytical chemistry. These include treatment of analytical data, chemical equilibria and quantitative analysis using titrimetric, electrochemical and chromatography methods.
courses.course_syllabus: treatment of analytical data, chemical equilibria and quantitative analysis using titrimetric, electrochemical and chromatography methods.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course Evaluation Questionnaire
Staff-Students Consultative Committee Meeting Report
External Examiner Report
courses.recommended_readings:
D. A. Skoog, D. M. West, F. J. Holler and S. R. Crouch: Fundamentals of Analytical Chemistry, 9th ed.
Chapters 5-7 (Treatment of Analytical Data)
Chapters 9-11 (Chemical Equilibria)
Chapter 2 (Titrimetric Methods – Chemicals & Apparatus)
Chapter 13 (Precipitation Titration)
Chapters 14-16 (Neutralization Titration)
Chapter 17 (Complexometric Titration)
Chapter 18 (Introduction to Electrochemistry)
Chapter 21 (Potentiometric Analysis)
Chapter 22 (Electrogravimetry & Coulumetry)
Chapter 23 (Voltammetry)
Chapter 29-33 (Kineics and Seperation)

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introductory Organic Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: This laboratory course covers the basic laboratory techniques for organic reactions and product isolation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: CHEM2200.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should have acquired:

- the knowledge of planning an experiment for isolating an organic compound from a mixture.

- the techniques for analysing the composition of an organic mixture.

- the basic laboratory techniques for separating and purifying an organic compound from a mixture.

- the techniques for isolating an enantiomers from a racemic mixture.

- the abilities to conduct literature/information search and write scientific reports.

- analytical skills, data analysis and critical thinking for problem solving.

- awareness of chemical safety.
courses.course_syllabus: This laboratory course covers the basic laboratory techniques for organic reactions and product isolation.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Course Evaluation Survey (for Laboratory Courses) – Conducted under Science of Faculty.

Conducted at the end of the course in the form of a questionnaire completed by students, to evaluate the effectiveness of

the course.

- Teaching Performance of Instructors and Demonstrators – Conducted under Department of Chemistry.

Conducted at the end of the course in the form of a questionnaire completed by students, to evaluate the teaching

performance of the instructors and demonstrators.

- Qualitative Feedbacks from Students

Feedbacks are collected from students informally about their opinions on the course. The feedbacks are collected through

the interactions between students and the instructor during the class sessions.

- Qualitative Feedbacks from Demonstrators

Feedbacks are collected from the lab demonstrators about their suggestions/comments on the course. Meetings

between demonstrators and the instructor are held to collect and discuss the feedbacks given by the demonstrators.

- Instructor’s reflection (Course teacher’s reflection)

The course materials/organization are regularly amended/adjusted with reference to:

a) Students’ feedbacks (qualitative and quantitative feedbacks)

b) Demonstrators’ feedbacks (qualitative feedbacks)

c) The learning needs of the students (designed/addressed by the course teacher/instructor)

d) Students’ performance in the course (qualitative – quality of their acquired skills and the laboratory reports submitted;
quantitatively – the actual marks obtained by the students)

e) Peers’ comments (teaching staff of related fields in the Department)
courses.required_readings: The laboratory manual provided for this course
courses.recommended_readings:
- Bruice, P. Y. Organic Chemistry, 6th Ed., Boston: Prentice Hall (2011).

- Lehman, J. W. Operational Organic Chemistry: A Problem-Solving Approach to the Laboratory Course, Upper Saddle River,

N.J.: Prentice Hall (1999).

- The articles specified in the Laboratory Manual

courses.description: This laboratory course covers the basic laboratory techniques and essential laboratory safety practices for carrying out organic and inorganic chemistry experiments. The experiments provide comprehensive training for students on (1) safe handling of chemical reagents and chemical waste; (2) proper usage of laboratory apparatus and equipment; (3) basic techniques of analyzing, isolating and purifying organic and inorganic compounds from a mixture; (4) common techniques for carrying out simple organic and inorganic reactions; (5) simple experimental techniques for identifying organic and inorganic compounds; (6) recording experimental data and writing experimental report, and; (7) conduct search on scientific literature. This course allows students to acquire experiences on fundamental organic and inorganic experimental practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CHEM2868.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to have:
1. safe handling of chemical reagents and chemical waste;
2. proper usage of laboratory apparatus and equipment;
3. basic techniques of analyzing, isolating and purifying organic and inorganic compounds from a mixture
4. common techniques for carrying out simple organic and inorganic reactions
5. simple experimental techniques for identifying organic and inorganic compounds
6. recording experimental data and writing experimental report
7. conduct search on scientific literature
8. analytical skills, data analysis and critical thinking for problem solving.
9. awareness of chemical safety.
courses.course_syllabus: This laboratory course covers the basic laboratory techniques and essential laboratory safety practices for carrying out organic and inorganic chemistry experiments. The experiments provide comprehensive training for students on (1) safe handling of chemical reagents and chemical waste; (2) proper usage of laboratory apparatus and equipment; (3) basic techniques of analyzing, isolating and purifying organic and inorganic compounds from a mixture; (4) common techniques for carrying out simple organic and inorganic reactions; (5) simple experimental techniques for identifying organic and inorganic compounds; (6) recording experimental data and writing experimental report, and; (7) conduct search on scientific literature. This course allows students to acquire experiences on fundamental organic and inorganic experimental practices.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course Evaluation Survey (for Laboratory Courses) – Conducted under Science of Faculty
Conducted at the end of the course in the form of a questionnaire completed by students, to evaluate the effectiveness of the course.

2. Teaching Performance of Instructors and Demonstrators – Conducted under Department of Chemistry
Conducted at the end of the course in the form of a questionnaire completed by students, to evaluate the teaching performance of the instructors and demonstrators.

3. Qualitative Feedbacks from Students
Feedbacks are collected from students informally about their opinions on the course. The feedbacks are collected through the interactions between students and the instructor during the class sessions.

4. Qualitative Feedbacks from Demonstrators
Feedbacks are collected from the lab demonstrators about their suggestions/comments on the course. Meetings between demonstrators and the instructor are held to collect and discuss the feedbacks given by the demonstrators.

5. Instructor’s reflection
The course materials/organization are regularly amended/adjusted with reference to:
- Students’ feedbacks (qualitative and quantitative feedbacks)
- Demonstrators’ feedbacks (qualitative feedbacks)
- The learning needs of the students (designed/addressed by the course teacher/instructor)
- Students’ performance in the course (qualitative – quality of their acquired skills and the laboratory reports submitted; quantitatively – the actual marks obtained by the students)
- Peers’ comments (teaching staff of related fields in the Department)
courses.required_readings:
Mandatory Reading:
- The laboratory manual provided for this course
courses.recommended_readings:
Suggested Reading:
- Kenneth L. W; Katherine M. M.; Organic Experiments Macroscale and Microscale, 6th Ed., Belmont, CA : Brooks/Cole (2011).

* common techniques for carrying out simple organic and inorganic reactions
* recording experimental data and writing experimental report
* analytical skills, data analysis and critical thinking for problem solving.
* awareness of chemical safety.

courses.description: This laboratory course covers the basic laboratory techniques and essential laboratory safety practices for carrying out analytical and physical chemistry experiments. The experiments provide comprehensive training for students on (1) safe handling of chemical reagents and chemical waste; (2) proper usage of laboratory apparatus and equipment; (3) basic techniques of determination of the properties of pure substances and solutions; (4) common techniques for qualitative and quantitative analysis of real samples; (5) fundamental procedures and techniques to investigate theories with experimental data and results; (6) recording, processing, and reporting experimental data and results, and; (7) conducting search on scientific literature. This course allows students to acquire experiences on fundamental analytical and physical experimental practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CHEM2878.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics in different areas of analytical chemistry and physical chemistry. Techniques in using computer in chemistry are also included.

2. Teaching Performance of Instructors and Demonstrators – Conducted under Department of Chemistry
Conducted at the end of the course in the form of a questionnaire completed by students, to evaluate the teaching performance of the instructors and demonstrators.

3. Qualitative Feedbacks from Students
Feedbacks are collected from students informally about their opinions on the course. The feedbacks are collected through the interactions between students and the instructor during the class sessions.

4. Qualitative Feedbacks from Demonstrators
Feedbacks are collected from the lab demonstrators about their suggestions/comments on the course. Meetings between demonstrators and the instructor are held to collect and discuss the feedbacks given by the demonstrators.

5. Instructor’s reflection
The course materials/organization are regularly amended/adjusted with reference to:
- Students’ feedbacks (qualitative and quantitative feedbacks)
- Demonstrators’ feedbacks (qualitative feedbacks)
- The learning needs of the students (designed/addressed by the course teacher/instructor)
- Students’ performance in the course (qualitative – quality of their acquired skills and the laboratory reports submitted; quantitatively – the actual marks obtained by the students)
- Peers’ comments (teaching staff of related fields in the Department)
courses.required_readings:
Mandatory Reading:
- The laboratory manual provided for this course
courses.recommended_readings:
Suggested Reading:
- D. A. Skoog, D. M. West, F. J. Holler and S. R. Crouch, “Fundamentals of Analytical Chemistry”, 9th ed., Brooks Cole, 2013.
- D. P. Shoemaker, C. W. Garland and J. W. Nibler, “Experiments in Physical Chemistry”, 6th Ed., McGraw-Hill (1996).
- P. W. Atkins, “Physical Chemistry”, 6th Ed., Oxford University Press (1998)

courses.description: Coordination chemistry: bonding, electronic spectra, magnetic properties, structure and isomerism, reactions, kinetics and mechanisms. Fundamentals of organometallic chemistry.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will have some basic understanding of coordination compounds of transition metals, including the ligand types and nomenclature.
2. Students will be able to account for the formation and explain some general properties of coordination compounds using valence bond theory, crystal field theory, and molecular orbital theory.
3. Students will learn how to study the extent of back-bonding in metal carbonyls.
4. Students will be able to assign electronic absorption spectra of octahedral and tetrahedral coordination compounds with the aid of different term diagrams.
5. Students will learn how to obtain information about the electronic configuration from magnetic properties of coordination compounds.
6. Students will be able to draw the possible structures of compounds with different coordination numbers (from 1 to 12).
7. Students will acquire knowledge of different types of isomerism.
8. Students will be able to suggest plausible mechanisms for ligand substitution and electron-transfer reactions of coordination compounds.
9. Students will acquire basic knowledge of modern organometallic chemistry, including the 18 valence electron rule, common ligands, reactions of organometallic complexes, and organometallic catalysis.
courses.course_syllabus: Coordination chemistry: bonding, electronic spectra, magnetic properties, structure and isomerism, reactions, kinetics and mechanisms. Fundamentals of organometallic chemistry
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation of this course will be based on (i) the results of course examinations and assignments, (ii) feedback from students through course evaluation, (iii) feedback from teaching assistants, and (iv) comments and suggestions made by the external examiners.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) J. E. Huheey, E. A. Keiter and R. L. Keiter, Inorganic Chemistry: Principles of Structure and Reactivity, fourth edition, Harper Collins, New York, 1993.
(2) G. E. Rodgers, Descriptive Inorganic, Coordination, and Solid-State Chemistry, third edition, Brooks/Cole, Singapore, 2012.
(3) G. L. Miessler, P. J. Fischer and D. A. Tarr, Inorganic Chemistry, fifth edition, Pearson, Harlow, 2014.
(4) C. Elschenbroich, Organometallics, third edition, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 2006.

courses.description: It includes: the chemistry of alcohols, phenols, ethers, epoxides, aldehydes and ketones, enolates.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CHEM2200.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students learn how to make use of pka values to explain the occurrence or no occurrence of an organic reaction.

2. Students learn how and why a given reaction step would occur with implications on regiochemistry and stereochemistry.

3. Students learn the fundamental concepts of structure- reactivity.

4. Students appreciate the in-depth introduction to mechanisms of single and multi-step reactions.

5. Students understand the importance of fundamental concepts and reaction mechanism in the explanation of the organic

chemistry reaction outcome: product selectivity with region- and stereo-selectivity.

6. Students learn various types of carbon-heteroatom and carbon-carbon formation reactions and can apply these reactions

to organic synthesis of organic molecules containing multi-oxygen functional groups.

7. Students are competent with reaction mechanisms.

This course provides the fundamental knowledge in organic chemistry and prepare students for advanced organic chemistry courses.

courses.description: This course covers chemistry of conjugated molecules including aromatic hydrocarbons, aromatic heterocyclces and pericyclic reactions, and provides an introduction to synthetic polymers mainly from a view of synthesis. This course emphasizes structure-reactivity relationship and application of basic principles of organic chemistry in practical problems. This course will train students with respect to the following capabilities and visions: understanding the complexities of matters at molecular level; presenting molecular structures of organic compounds correctly and clearly; understanding mechanisms of important organic reactions; defining and analyzing practical problems of environment, health and sustainable development based on chemical structures and reactions; divergent and convergent thinking in planning organic synthesis; fundamental ideas in designing and producing materials and medicines at molecular level.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CHEM3220.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
• Understand the relationship between structure and reactivity of conjugated molecules.
• Present organic reaction mechanisms using electron arrow diagrams.
• Understand fundamental concepts of synthetic polymers and synthetic methods to produce them
• Relate chemistry of conjugated molecules and synthetic polymers to daily life application.
courses.course_syllabus: This course covers chemistry of conjugated molecules including aromatic hydrocarbons, aromatic heterocyclces and pericyclic reactions, and provides a brief introduction to synthetic polymers. Fundamental concepts and important reaction mechanisms of conjugated molecules and synthetic polymers, such as aromaticity, electrophilic aromatic substitution reaction, the conservation of orbital symmetry theory and chain-growth polymerization, will be emphasized.

courses.description: Statistical mechanics and kinetic theory of gases. Treatment of molecular speeds, Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution and simple hard-sphere collision. Theoretical foundation of the rate equation. Catalysis. Experimental kinetics and gas reactions. Fick’s laws and transport phenomena in gases/liquids.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Understand the relevance of Chemical Kinetics and Reaction Dynamics to solving important global issue such as Chemistry of the Ozone depletion in the Stratosphere and to day to day consumer goods. Through this topic, the students were taught the following concepts:
• Statistical concept such as the Boltzman and Boltzman-Maxwell distribution in the development of chemistry problems.
• Steady state principle to solving kinetic problems.
• Transport theory such as Fick’s Law
• Kinetic theories such as Collision Theory and Transition-State Theory
Through the discussion of industrial applications, students were taught the concepts of
• Solution transport phenomena and Fick’s second Law
• Adsorption and Chemisorption and how it is applied in industrial processes and development of consumer goods
• Heterogeneous reaction systems and the Langmuir theory, the BET theory.
The students were also briefly exposed to very simple biological chemistry and some of the most common mechanistic solutions.

The students were trained to acquire problem solving skill set such as
• determining fundamental kinetic parameters from experimental data
• designing second order kinetic experiments
• calculating reaction rate constant k on statistical basis
courses.course_syllabus: Statistical mechanics and kinetic theory of gases. Treatment of molecular speeds, Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution and simple hard-sphere collision. Theoretical foundation of the rate equation. Catalysis. Experimental kinetics and gas reactions. Fick’s laws and transport phenomena in gases/liquids.

courses.description: The course divides into two main parts, namely spectrophotometry and separation sciences. Spectrophotometry covers electromagnetic radiation; interactions between photons and matters; UV-visible atomic absorption spectrometry; UV-visible molecular absorption spectrometry; infrared molecular absorption spectrometry; atomic emission spectrometry; X-ray absorption spectrometry; and X-ray fluorescence spectrometry. Separation sciences include an introduction of the principles of chromatographic separation; gas chromatography (GC); high performance liquid chromatography (LC); mass spectrometer as a sample-selective detector for GC/LC; supercritical fluid chromatography; and capillary electrophoresis.
courses.learning_outcomes: The students acquired a general understanding of the fundamental aspects of various instrumental methods used in common analytical laboratories. Basic handling of analytical data generated from various analysis was taught through series of assignments and laboratory works. Hand-on experience on the operation of several key instruments was provided through the six practical sessions.

Separation sciences include an introduction of the principles of chromatographic separation; gas chromatography (GC); high performance liquid chromatography (LC); mass spectrometer as a sample-selective detector for GC/LC; supercritical fluid chromatography; and capillary electrophoresis.

courses.description: This laboratory course includes experiments of various important reaction classes. Examples of these reactions are nucleophilic substitution, addition reactions, elimination reactions, epoxidation, oxidation and reduction reactions of organic compounds, reactions involve enols and carbanions, electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions, etc. These experiments allow students to acquire in-depth understanding of reactivity, selectivity and the mechanisms of the various types of important organic reactions. This course strengthens students’ skills for carrying out organic reactions, and their experience in determining the structures of organic compounds by spectroscopic methods. After completion of this course, students should be able to carry out simple organic synthesis reactions, purify the reaction products by using the appropriate techniques, and identify the structures of the reaction products by IR and NMR spectroscopy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CHEM2860 or CHEM2868. Co-requisite: CHEM3220.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should have acquired:
1. the knowledge of planning an experiment for carrying out an organic reaction or isolating an organic compound from a
mixture.
2. the laboratory techniques for carrying out organic reactions.
3. the techniques for analysing the composition of an organic mixture.
4. the chemistry of and the practical techniques for carrying out some important organic reactions (e.g. Grignard reaction,
Wittig olefination, epoxidation, oxidations and reductions involving alcohols and carbonyl compounds, addition and
condensation reactions involving carbanions and enols, etc.).
5. the techniques for analysing/elucidating the structures of organic compounds by spectroscopic methods.
6. abilities to conduct literature/information search and write scientific reports.
7. analytical skills, data analysis and critical thinking for problem solving.
8. awareness of chemical safety.

courses.description: Co-requisite: CHEM3230. This laboratory course comprised of experiments mainly focus on some advanced practices in organic synthesis, including advanced organic reaction techniques, multi-step organic synthesis and catalytic organic reactions. The course aims to strengthen students’ experience on carrying out more advanced and complicated practical tasks in organic chemistry, and understanding the essential principles in planning a multi-step organic synthesis route.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: CHEM3230.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should have acquired:

- the knowledge and experience of planning experiments for carrying out organic reactions and multi-step organic synthesis.
- the knowledge about the chemistry and mechanisms of, and the practical techniques for carrying out some important
organic reactions involving amines, arenes, heterocyclic compounds, and macrocycles.
- the techniques for identifying the structures of organic compounds by spectroscopic methods.
- abilities to conduct literature/information search and write scientific reports.
- analytical skills, data analysis and critical thinking for problem solving.
- awareness of chemical safety.

courses.description: Laboratory work covers inorganic synthesis, modern techniques of analysis and experiments designed to illustrate the fundamental principles of coordination chemistry.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CHEM2860 or CHEM2868. Co-requisite: CHEM3130.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will have some basic understanding of coordination compounds of transition metals, including the ligand types
and nomenclature.
2. Students will be able to account for the formation and explain some general properties of coordination compounds using
valence bond theory, crystal field theory, and molecular orbital theory.
3. Students will learn how to study the extent of back-bonding in metal carbonyls.
4. Students will be able to assign electronic absorption spectra of octahedral and tetrahedral coordination compounds with
the aid of different term diagrams.
5. Students will learn how to obtain information about the electronic configuration from magnetic properties of coordination
compounds.
6. Students will be able to draw the possible structures of compounds with different coordination numbers (from 1 to 12).
7. Students will acquire knowledge of different types of isomerism.
8. Students will be able to suggest plausible mechanisms for ligand substitution and electron-transfer reactions of
coordination compounds.
9. Students will appreciate the various applications of transition metal complexes.

courses.description: This is a practical course in analytical chemistry which covers various instrumental techniques and training in experimental analytical chemistry. The principles of instrumental analysis are also illustrated through experiments. The topics of the experiments are in various types including for example, spectrophotometric methods including atomic absorption and emission and x-ray fluorescence, chromatographic separation methods and mass spectrometry. Students are required to prepare for the experiments by understanding and analyzing the goal of the experiment. They also need to search for knowledge and information from diverse channels such as assigned textbooks, literature, and internet resources available to them.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CHEM2870 or CHEM2872 or CHEM2878. Co-requisite: CHEM3410.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students should have acquired,
- a general understanding of the fundamental aspects of various instrumental methods used in common analytical
laboratories
- basic handling of analytical data generated from various analysis
- hands-on experience on the operation of several key instruments
- treatments of real samples before putting into the instruments for measurements

courses.description: This is a practical course in analytical chemistry which covers various chemical tests performed in the accredited laboratories of the society. Quality assurance of the chemical test is illustrated through experiments and it includes the use of certified reference material, calibration of equipment and the use of spiked sample during measurements. Students are required to prepare for the experiments by understanding and analyzing the goals of the experiment. They also need to search for knowledge and information from diverse channels such as assigned textbooks, literature, and internet resources available to them. Co-requisite: CHEM3420
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: CHEM3420.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to have:

 To understand the operation of chemical testing laboratory.
 To apply classroom knowledge in actual working environment.
 To learn to appreciate the role of accredited laboratory in the economy
 To know how to perform method validation
 To understand what measurement traceability is
 To know how to quantify measurement uncertainty for a specific analytical method

courses.description: Course to be followed by CHEM4020 in the second term.This final year project will be of problem-based type in the area of analytical chemistry. Students will be, either individually or divided into small groups, to carry out hands-on experiments on projects prescribed, and to solve problems encountered during the process. At the end of the project, each group is required to give an oral presentation and to submit a written report on the project.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to have:

Students will learn various spectroscopic and experimental techniques in the area of analytical chemistry.
Students will learn skills in technical writing and oral presentation.
Students will learn the processes in searching the literature when solving problems in the fields of analytical chemistry.
Students will learn the communication skills among the fellow group mates.
Students will learn how to coordinate and manage a scientific project.

courses.description: This course aims to provide students a deeper understanding of modern inorganic chemistry. The concept of molecular symmetry as well as the elements and applications of group theory will be introduced. Two or more of the following topics will also be covered: metal clusters, advanced main group chemistry, inorganic catalysis, inorganic materials, lanthanide and rare-earth metal chemistry, and photochemistry and photoredox catalysis.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are expected to have understanding on molecular symmetry and group theory.
2. Students will be able to do point group assignment and use character tables.
3. Students will learn the applications of group theory in molecular vibrations and bonding theories.
4. Students will learn advanced topics in main group chemistry.
5. Students will have some basic understanding on rare-earth chemistry.
courses.course_syllabus:
| The concept of molecular symmetry as well as the elements and applications of group theory will be introduced. Two or more of the following topics will also be covered: metal clusters, advanced main group chemistry, inorganic catalysis, inorganic materials, lanthanide and rare-earth metal chemistry, and photochemistry and photoredox catalysis. |
| --- |
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term evaluation in the form of questionnaires will be performed.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. F. A. Cotton, G. Wilkinson, C. A. Murillo and M. Bochmann, Advanced Inorganic Chemistry, Wiley, New York, 6th ed., 1999.
2. W.-K. Li, G.-D. Zhou and T. C. W. Mak, Advanced Structural Inorganic Chemistry, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2008.
3. F. A. Cotton, Chemical Applications of Group Theory, Wiley, New York, 3rd ed., 1990.

meetings.instructor: Professor WAN Qingyun

courses.description: Organic electronics, such as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), are commonly used in various aspects of our daily lives. This course covers the basics of organic electronic devices such as OLEDs, organic field-effect transistors (OFETs), and organic solar cells (OSCs). It explores their working principles, device structures, and other relevant aspects. Additionally, fundamental physical properties related to luminescence and conductivity will be discussed, focusing on molecular materials.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Understand the electronic structures of organic molecular materials and band structures of solid-state materials.
* Understand the photo-physical properties and electronic conductivities of organic materials.
* Understand the working principle of Organic Light-Emitting Diode (OLED), Organic Field-Effect Transistor (OFET) and Organic Solar Cell (OSC).
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Week 1-2:** **Organic Semiconductor Materials, Electronic Structures, Atomic and Molecular Orbitals**

* *Week 3-4:** **Basic Photophysical Parameters and Spectroscopic Methods**

* *Week 5-6:** **Excited Molecules, Optical Process (****Energy Transfer and Exciton Diffusion) in Organic Semiconductor**

* *Week 7-8:** **Fermi Level and Band Structure. Electrical Current and Carrier Transport.**

* *Week 9-10:** **Charge Carrier Recombination, Dissociation of Excitations**

* *Week 11-13:** **Operational Principle of an OFET, OLED and OSC**
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Here are some common sources of feedback information that can be collected for evaluating a course:

1. Student Surveys: Distributing surveys to students at the end of the course to gather their feedback on various aspects such as course content, teaching methods, assignments, and overall satisfaction.
2. Assessment Results: Analysing student performance on assignments and exams to learn about the effectiveness of the course content and teaching methods.
3. Reaching out to former students to gather feedback on the course and its impact on their learning and professional development.
courses.required_readings: Electronic Processes in Organic Semiconductors. Edited by Anna Köhler and Heinz Bässler. 2015, Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Boschstr. 12, 69469 Weinheim, Germany
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Organic Electronics II. Edited by Hagen Klauk. 2012, Wiley-VCH Verlag & Co. KGaA, Boschstr. 12, 69469 Weinheim, Germany
2. Organic Electronics. Materials, Manufacturing and Applications. Edited by Hagen Klauk. 2006, WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Bioorganic Chemistry and Chemical Biology
courses.description: This course will introduce bioorganic chemistry and chemical biology to senior undergraduate students who have learned basic organic chemistry courses. The course has two modules. First module is bioorganic chemistry: chemical structures, reactions, synthesis, and functions of biomolecules. The lecturer will first introduce four types of biomolecules, namely peptides and proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and nucleic acids to chemistry students, with a focus on their molecular structures, higher-order structures and organizations, and the organic reactions to synthesize or to transform these molecules in a synthetic laboratory or inside cells. Enzymes, a special group of proteins will also be introduced to the audience, together with cofactors and coenzymes as one example of proteins possessing catalytic power. The second module of the course will focus on chemical biology, including current technologies developed and selected research projects in this field. Through this course, students will be able to apply their basic organic chemistry knowledge to complicated biological molecules, and deepen their understanding on molecules in life, from an organic chemist's point of view. This course will be distinct from an introductory biochemistry course by focusing on the organic chemistry aspects of the molecules in life, i.e. molecular structures, higher-order structures, functional groups, transformations, reactions and syntheses.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CHEM2200.
courses.learning_outcomes: Learn the basics of the structures, reactions, and functions of biomolecules from the aspect of organic chemistry, the enzymatic mechanisms, and current frontiers of chemical biology.
courses.course_syllabus:
Module I, The structure, reaction and function of biomolecules. The lecturer will first introduce four types of biomolecules, peptides and proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and nucleic, with a focus on their molecular structures, higher-order structures and organizations, and the organic reactions to synthesize or to transform these molecules in a synthetic laboratory or inside cells. The mechanisms of bioreactions. Enzymes, a special group of proteins will also be introduced to the audience, together with cofactors and coenzymes as one example of proteins possessing catalytic power.

Module II. Recent advances of chemical biology, including newly developed technologies and research topics, through literature reviews and guest lectures.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The lecturer will collect students’ opinions on the course through informal and formal communication with the students during classes. If possible, senior teachers will be invited to the lecture hall during class to collect their opinion to help the teacher improve the teaching of this course.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Chemistry in Biofuel
courses.description: Biofuel, namely fuel produced through chemical engineering processes of biomass, represents a major alternative and sustainable source of energy. The course covers review of organic chemistry and physical chemistry; structures and combustion energy of fuel molecules; related biochemistry and enzymology; biochemical conversion processes; ethanol production from carbohydrate-based biomass; biodiesel production from lipid-based biomass; hydrogen and methane production from organic and waste products; fermentation and alkane production; chemical engineering processes of biofuel production; biofuel economics, policies, and research and development; field trip to bioenergy farm. A guest lecture from a practitioner on biofuel production industry is scheduled. Students are required to run experiments for a project and to design their own solutions to solve problems met in biofuel industry.
courses.learning_outcomes: This is an elective course designed for fourth year Engineering undergraduate student in 4-year curriculum who are interested in learning the chemical and biochemical basis of biofuels, metabolic engineering, and the technologies of sustainable energy source. Students are expected to understand the topics in biofuel products, learn the terminologies of bioenergy, and be able to read and understand articles about metabolic engineering and biofuel production.
courses.course_syllabus: The course covers review of organic chemistry and physical chemistry; structures and combustion energy of fuel molecules; related biochemistry and enzymology; biochemical conversion processes; ethanol production from carbohydrate-based biomass; biodiesel production from lipid-based biomass; hydrogen and methane production from organic and waste products; fermentation and alkane production; chemical engineering processes of biofuel production; biofuel economics, policies, and research and development; field trip to bioenergy farm. A guest lecture from a practitioner on biofuel production industry is scheduled. Students are required to run experiments for a project and to design their own solutions to solve problems met in biofuel industry.

1. Biofuels: Thinking Clearly about the Issues, J. Agric. Food Chem. 2008, 56, 3885–3891
2. Bioinspired chemistry for energy, Sandi Schwartz, Tina Masciangioli, and Boonchai Boonyaratanakornkit. Washington,
D.C. : National Academies Press, c2008.

6. Biofuels Engineering Process Technology by Cave Drapcho, John Nghiem, and Terry Walker, McGraw Hill Publications.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Food Testing and Environmental Analysis

meetings.instructor: Professor TAM Shuk Ching Elaine
Professor TAM Shuk Ching Elaine

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a solid understanding of the approaches to solving both episodic and routine issues in our food and environment using chemical analyses. Students will learn the basic principles of analysis, including sampling, sample treatment, analyte identification and assay. Through various detailed examples, students will learn the classical and instrumental methods used in food and environmental analyses and, more importantly, the rationale for method selection. Related local and international regulations and protocols will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CHEM2400. Co-requisite: CHEM3410.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected, for the different food and environmental analyses, to do the following:

1. When given a method, to breakdown the procedure into the different steps of sampling, treatment, identification and assay and apply the required precautions and knowledge for the successful completion of these steps
2. When given a sample, to understand its analytical requirements and to apply their knowledge in the selection of a more appropriate method
3. When given a special sample having no well-known analysis methods, to suggest possible methods for its analysis
4. When carrying out the analysis, as well as communications with clients, to know and follow the updated quality requirements for an accredited laboratory

Through various detailed examples, students will learn the classical and instrumental methods used in food and environmental analyses and, more importantly, the rationale for method selection. Related local and international regulations and protocols will also be discussed.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Advanced Environmental Chemistry

meetings.instructor: Dr. CHAN Ka Long Donald
Dr. CHAN Ka Long Donald
Dr. CHAN Ka Long Donald
Dr. CHAN Ka Long Donald

courses.description: This course is designed to extend students' understanding of and develop their ability in the application of various aspects of environmental chemistry in relation to the major types of air and water pollution associated with industrial and vehicle emissions. It outlines the basic processes in bleaching and dyeing, electroplating, power generation and semiconductor manufacturing that give rise to water pollution and application of physico-chemical techniques in controlling such pollution. It also examines the applications and limitations of absorption, adsorption, oxidation-reduction and catalytic conversion techniques in relation to reducing aerial emissions. The development of green chemistry and cleaner production towards solving the chemical pollution problems are extensively discussed.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will become familiar with air and water pollution associated with industrial and vehicle emissions. They will be able to evaluate the basic pollution control and prevention approaches in bleaching and dyeing, electroplating and electronics industries.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Chemical pollutants
2. Chemical hazards
3. Metal finishing industry
4. Electronics industry
5. Textile industry
6. Green chemistry and cleaner production
7. Environmental catalysis
8. Sustainable energy and energy utilization

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Chemical Treatment Process
courses.description: This course introduces the principles and applications of various chemical and physiochemical processes applicable for treatment and control of air, water and soil pollution. It studies the processes of neutralization, oxidation-reduction, chemical precipitation, coagulation, flocculation, physical separation, absorption, adsorption, filtration, chemical disinfection, solvent extraction, fractional distillation and incineration. It also examines the applicability and limitations of such processes with reference to the treatment and recovery of toxic and hazardous chemical wastes. Site visits will be arranged where possible to enhance students' ability in application.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will become familiar with various chemical and physico-chemical processes applicable for treatment and control of air and water pollution. They will be able to evaluate the applicability and limitations of such processes with reference to the treatment and recovery of toxic and hazardous chemical wastes.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Chemical contamination in Penny's Bay, Hong Kong
2. Hong Kong dioxin studies
3. Treatment of dioxins
4. Treatment of heavy metals
5. Water treatment
6. Databases for chemical treatment
7. Overview of emerging technologies
8. Advanced oxidation processes
9. Nanotechnology for environmental applications
10. Management of Fukushima nuclear wastewater

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Asymmetric Organic Synthesis

meetings.instructor: Professor YEUNG Ying Yeung
Professor YEUNG Ying Yeung
Professor YEUNG Ying Yeung
Professor YEUNG Ying Yeung

courses.description: Modern organic synthesis requires the construction of molecules in an enantiopure form (asymmetric synthesis) because the (+)- and the (-)-enantiomer display different pharmacological response. This advanced organic chemistry course focuses on protocols for diastereoselective and enantioselective carbon-carbon formation. Contemporary organocatalytic reactions involving carbon-carbon formation and carbon-heteroatom formation are also covered. Examples on the syntheses of chiral drug molecules are illustrated.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Through the chiral structures of drug molecules, students learn advanced 3-dimensional stereochemistry and appreciate

the importance of stereochemistry with regards to drug-enzyme interaction and drug-receptor interaction.

2. Students learn the logic, rationale, and stereochemistry control of the enantio- as well as diasetereo-selective carbon-

carbon formation reactions which is the core of asymmetric synthesis.

3. Students learn modern organocatalytic reactions and appreciate that these reactions are metal-free and are considered

to be a kind of green chemistry.

4. Students know how to apply the enantio- as well as diasetereo-selective reactions in the stereo-controlled synthesis of a

chiral organic molecule.

5. Students learn to design asymmetric synthesis of a drug molecule and its analogs using the protocols described in this

course

6. Students appreciate how asymmetric organic synthesis is essential to the pharmaceutical industry and is the

indispensable component for the discovery of new medicine.
courses.course_syllabus: This advanced organic chemistry course focuses on protocols for diastereoselective and enantioselective carbon-carbon formation. Contemporary organocatalytic reactions involving carbon-carbon formation and carbon-heteroatom formation are also covered. Examples on the syntheses of chiral drug molecules are illustrated.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Quantum Chemistry
courses.description: This course is designed to train senior undergraduate students to do practical quantum chemistry calculations. An overview will be provided about the basic principles, with emphasis on the basic concepts, rather than the mathematical details. Practical problems are covered, so that a student learns how to solve chemical problems by computation.Theoretical Overview: Many electron problems, the Slater determinants, the calculation of one-centre and two-centre integrals, Hartree-Fock method, Linear combination of atomic orbitals, the variation principle. Post-Hartree-Fock treatment and Density Functional Theory. Practical consideration: choice of basis sets; typical xc-functional for DFT. Practical problems: geometry optimization, potential energy surface, optimization of transition states, calculation of harmonic frequencies, energetics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to acquire knowledge in the following areas:

* Students are expected to understand the basic principles underlying Hartree-Fock method, post-Hartree-Fock treatment to address the electron correlation problem, and DFT methods for modeling the chemical bonding and electronic structure of molecules.
* They should develop hands-on skills to do such calculations using the Gaussian package to model the geometry, bonding and electronic structure of molecules.
* They should be able to understand the computational results now widely reported in the chemical literature.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Theoretical Overview: Many electron problems, the Slater determinants, the calculation of one-centre and two-centre integrals, Hartree-Fock method, Linear combination of atomic orbitals, the variation principle. Post-Hartree-Fock treatment and Density Functional Theory.
2. Practical consideration: choice of basis sets; typical xc-functional for DFT.
3. Practical problems: geometry optimization, potential energy surface, optimization of transition states, calculation of harmonic frequencies, energetics.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course Evaluation Questionnaire
Staff-Students Consultative Committee Meeting Report
External Examiner Report
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Hehre, W. J. (2003). A Guide to Molecular Mechanics and Quantum Chemical Calculations
2. Lewars, E. (2010). Computational chemistry introduction to the theory and applications of molecular and quantum mechanics.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Mass Spectrometry

meetings.instructor: Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic
Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic
Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with the fundamental concepts and applications of mass spectrometry. It consists of several core modules including desorption/ionization techniques, ion activation methods, mass analysers and ion detectors. The use of mass spectrometry methods for structural elucidation of small organic molecules. Theory of unimolecular decomposition and simple mass spectral interpretation will be taught. Biological applications of mass spectrometry, including genomic, proteomic and glycomic applications, will also be taught.
courses.learning_outcomes: The student should acquire a comprehensive understanding of the operation of mass spectrometry methods. This includes an understanding of the information that can be derived from a mass spectrometry analysis, the principles of various desorption / ionization methods, mass analysers, ion activation methods in mass spectrometry. The students should appreciate the complexity of proteomic, genomic and glycomic research and understand the role of mass spectrometry in these important disciplines of research.
courses.course_syllabus: This course consists of several core modules including ionization (desorption/ionization) techniques, ion activation methods, mass analysers and ion detectors. The use of mass spectrometry methods for structural elucidation of small organic. Theory of unimolecular decomposition and simple mass spectral interpretation will be taught. Biological applications of mass spectrometry, including genomic, proteomic and glycomic applications, will also be taught.

courses.description: This course reviews analytical methods to solve biological problems. It serves as a primer to the expanding field of bioanalysis. The topics covered by this course include: purification and separation, spectroscopic methods; electrophoresis; mass spectroscopy; chromatography; NMR; analysis of nucleic acids; protein sequencing; immunoanalysis, single molecule technique; single cell analysis; etc.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The students will gain the basic knowledge of biochemistry

The students will know the general available methods for biological problems

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Industrial Chemistry
courses.description: Industrial chemistry plays a vital role as an applied science in diverse areas that influence human society, ranging from economic, environmental to political stability. This course explores the relationship between industrial activities and their importance to our society. Students will learn important chemical processes used in industry, ranging from the large-scale production of bulk chemical commodities, industrial gases, fertilizers, petrochemicals and polymers. The course will also examine the emerging environmental issues related to the expanding industrial activity and discuss the future industries based on insights from environmental chemistry.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• The students are able to define, describe, and apply basic chemical processes involved in the production of major

commercial products used in society.

• The students are able to develop critical skill at analysing the cost and impact of traditional industrial chemical processes

on society.

• The students will know the basic principle of sustainable industrial chemical processes with low impact on the

environment and human health.
courses.course_syllabus: This course explores the relationship between industrial activities and their importance to our society. Students will learn important chemical processes used in industry, ranging from the large-scale production of bulk chemical commodities, industrial gases, fertilizers, petrochemicals and polymers. The course will also examine the emerging environmental issues related to the expanding industrial activity and discuss the future industries based on insights from environmental chemistry.

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic metals commonly used in industry and the chemistry and application engineering of protective coatings to these substrates. Both electro and chemical metallic deposition, are discussed besides anodizing. Organic coating and sacrificial protection are also discussed in the course. Apart from principles and chemical theories, there are discussions and examples of industrial production processes and quality control specifications for protective coatings.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Possess general knowledge of metals commonly used in industry, their specifications, applicability and commercial availability.
2. Understand corrosion chemistry and metallic protection.
3. Possess general knowledge on coating chemistry and the various coating technologies.
4. Understand metallic passivation and non-electrodeposition protection chemistry.
5. Enhance confidence in job interviews and converse technically in metal-related industrial processes.

Possess basic knowledge of metals on engaging in a metal-related industrial or commercial employment.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will cover the following topics

a) Introduction to metals and alloys used in industry - chemical compositions, specifications, applications and coating pretreatment.

b) Inorganic coatings - principles, applications and corrosion protection.

c) Organic coatings - principles, applications and corrosion protection

d) Other anti-corrosion techniques - principles and applications of cathodic protection and anodizing.

courses.description: Forensic sciences form a vital part of modern judiciary system. Chemical examinations have been used extensively in the search for crucial evidence at scenes of crime, exhibits identification and comparison, which in turn provide valuable and scientifically-based information for the court to form its judgement. This course will show students how to apply their acquired chemical knowledge in the retrieval of crucial evidence and exhibit examinations to generate information of evidential value to assist law enforcement agencies to find out the truth of cases encountered.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Colloids and Surface Chemistry
courses.description: Colloids are of increasing importance in both industry and academics. Not only do many commercial products involve colloids, but research in modern chemistry, biology, material science, and physics often require knowledge of the colloidal domain. This course will give the student an introduction to the physico-chemical principles governing surface phenomena and the properties of colloidal materials. We will explore the interactions and self-organization on the nanometer and micron scale with great relevance for material engineering as well as biological processes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MPhil-PhD Chemistry
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to acquire knowledge in the following areas:

1. Learn the basic concepts related to surface chemistry and colloidal materials.
2. Develop an understanding for colloidal stability and the interaction forces between the colloidal particles.
3. Explore the interactions and self-organization on the nanometer and micron scale that closely related to material
engineering as well as biological systems.
4. Understand the link between the physicochemical properties of materials which affect the design of modern
formulation in cosmetic, food and pharmaceutical dosage.
courses.course_syllabus: Colloids are of increasing importance in both industry and academics. Not only do many commercial products involve colloids, but research in modern chemistry, biology, material science, and physics often require knowledge of the colloidal domain. This course will give the student an introduction to the physico-chemical principles governing surface phenomena and the properties of colloidal materials. We will explore the interactions and self-organization on the nanometer and micron scale with great relevance for material engineering as well as biological processes.

courses.description: This course aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the requirements of the International Standard for laboratory accreditation based on ISO/IEC 17025. It also focuses on applying internal auditing skills of testing laboratory with an elaboration on relevant technical issues required for monitoring performance of work and the follow-up tools. Emphasis is also given to the practices and applications of laboratory management system to improve the reliability and productivity of laboratories.

Learning Outcomes:
• Students should understand the principles and requirements of International Standard ISO/IEC 17025
• Students should be able to establish, implement and maintain an effective laboratory management system
• Students should understand the principles of internal audit
• Students should understand the accreditation processes and be able to undertake structured preparation for assessment by various accreditation bodies, such as the Hong Kong Accreditation Service (HKAS) and the China National Accreditation Service for Conformity Assessment (CNAS)

Emphasis is also given to the practices and applications of laboratory management system to improve the reliability and productivity of laboratories.

courses.title: Measurement Uncertainty

meetings.instructor:
Professor LI Hung Wing, 
Professor SZE Tung Po Eric

Professor LI Hung Wing, 
Professor SZE Tung Po Eric

Professor LI Hung Wing, 
Professor SZE Tung Po Eric

courses.description: This core course aims to engage students in the critical analysis and application of different statistical tools for the treatment of data from chemical analysis. Participants will explore from foundational concepts to emerging techniques, including probability density functions, descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, linear regression and principal component analysis.Besides, a significant focus will be placed on the examination of the measurement uncertainty by different approaches, including JCGM GUM-1 and EURACHEM/CITAC Guide. Finally, emerging technique using Monte Carlo simulations will be introduced for uncertainty estimation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Students from MSc of Accreditation Chemistry only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to

* analyze data from chemical analysis using various statistical principles and techniques
* construct the model and evaluate measurement uncertainty using approaches of JCGM GUM-1 and EURACHEM/CITAC Guide
* differentiate different types of standard uncertainty and combine standard uncertainty components into combined uncertainty
* report the measurement uncertainty in test reports and determine the compliance of test results in consideration of measurement uncertainty
courses.course_syllabus:
This core course aims to engage students in the critical analysis and application of different statistical tools for the treatment of data from chemical analysis. Participants will explore from foundational concepts to emerging techniques, including probability density functions, descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, linear regression and principal component analysis.

Besides, a significant focus will be placed on the examination of the measurement uncertainty by different approaches, including JCGM GUM-1 and EURACHEM/CITAC Guide. Finally, emerging technique using Monte Carlo simulations will be introduced for uncertainty estimation.

courses.title: Forensic Sciences and Doping Control

meetings.instructor: Professor LI Hung Wing
Professor LI Hung Wing

courses.description: Forensic science plays a crucial role in modern judicial systems by providing scientific evidence that aids the court in forming accurate judgments. Chemical examinations are extensively used in the identification and comparison of exhibits, offering valuable insights to support legal proceedings. This course provides an overview of the diverse disciplines within forensic science, the common types of evidence encountered at crime scenes, and doping control. It also introduces students to essential analytical methods and techniques, including chromatography, spectroscopy, and microscopy, which are commonly employed by forensic scientists. Through this course, students will learn how to apply their chemical knowledge to the examination of exhibits, generating information of evidential value to assist law enforcement agencies in uncovering the truth behind cases.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Students from MSc of Accreditation Chemistry only
courses.learning_outcomes: The course is designed to equip students with a strong foundation in forensic chemical analysis, enabling them to identify chemical items of evidential value and understand their significance in investigations. By the end of the course, students will have a clear understanding of the proper handling of evidence — a critical skill in ensuring the integrity of investigations and the successful identification and conviction of criminals.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will empower students to use forensic analytical techniques and chemical expertise in examining exhibits:

1. Principles of forensic sciences
2. Analytical methods for forensic sciences
3. Vibrational spectroscopy in forensic chemistry
4. Forensic analysis in Textiles
5. Forensic analysis in paint and coatings
6. Forensic analysis in glass and soil
7. Purpose and rules for controlling prohibited substances in sports
8. Sample collection and methodologies in doping control testing
9. Challenges and quality assurance in doping control testing
10. Post-detection investigations and test results management
11. Factors affecting drug clearance and drug detection time
12. Case studies and measures to avoid inadvertent violations

These spectroscopic techniques include flame and electrothermal atomic absorption spectrometry, plasma atomic emission spectrometry, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry and X-ray fluorescence spectrometry. Selected applications of analytical atomic spectrometry will be discussed in details.
