- Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry
- Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry
- X-Ray Fluorescence Spectrometry
- Sample Preparation for Atomic Spectrometry
- Hyphenated Techniques for Speciation of Organometallic Compounds
- Applications of Analytical Atomic Spectrometry

meetings.instructor: Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic

courses.description: This course intends to provide an in-depth knowledge on the advanced chromatographic and mass spectrometric methods for characterization of different materials, including synthetic (such as drugs and polymers) and naturally available molecules (such as proteins and DNAs). This course starts with a review of the principles and instrumentation of standalone chromatography and mass spectrometry methods. This is followed by the principles and applications of various tandem and hyphenated techniques involving either or both chromatography and mass spectrometry.

courses.learning_outcomes:
• Students should understand the principles of various mass spectrometric and chromatographic techniques in testing laboratories
• Students should be able to validate the performance of instruments
• Students should be able to interpret simple chromatograms and mass spectra
• Students should be able to apply different control tools in operations to optimize the quality of results

This course will also discuss the various modes of on-line separation and identification techniques involving both chromatography and mass spectrometry methods.

courses.description: This course aims to provide a comprehensive knowledge of risk management in chemical testing laboratories regarding environmental protection, food safety, occupational health and safety. Topics encompass relevant local regulations and international standards for risk management in environmental protection, food safety, hazard analysis and critical control points (HACCP) principles, occupational health and safety. International management systems, namely ISO 17025, ISO 14001, ISO 45001 and ISO2200 standards are discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Students from MSc of Accreditation Chemistry only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Understanding of the requirements of management systems of environmental protection and occupational health & safety in chemical testing laboratories.
• Understanding of the risk management as required by ISO 17025 and associated standards regarding environmental protection, food safety and occupational health and safety.
• Knowing to plan and implement risk management to meet the requirements of the respective management standards and their certification.
• Knowing the importance of continual enhancement of the laboratory’s management in environmental protection, food safety, HACCP principles, and occupational health and safety.
courses.course_syllabus: This course covers the principles and practice of risk management with reference to ISO 17025 and international management standards for environmental protection, food safety, occupational health, and safety regarding chemical issues. Topics will include local and international laws, and risk management for chemical testing laboratory operations.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Metrology in Chemistry
courses.description: Traceability and comparability of chemical measurements are fundamental to harmonization of international measurement standards and mutual recognition of measurement results, which serves as a basis for global agreements related to international trade, commerce and regulatory issues. This course provides an in-depth discussion on the international metrology framework, the significance of traceability and comparability of chemical measurements in seeking accreditation of test methods, the selection and use of inter-laboratory comparisons and certified reference materials in test method validation, and the use of international standards in calibration and performance verification of analytical instruments.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Students from MSc of Accreditation Chemistry only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• After the course, students should understand the global metrology infrastructure for chemical measurements, and its significance in international trade and other aspects
• They should be able to establish traceability in their measurements
• They should be able to evaluate and select appropriate reference materials for use in method validation and verification
• They should be able to evaluate the results of inter-laboratory comparisons
• They should be able to adopt appropriate international recommendations in verification of instrument performance

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Bioinorganic Chemistry
courses.description: An overview of bioinorganic chemistry. Principles of coordination chemistry related to bioinorganic research. Biomolecules: proteins, nucleic acids and other metal-binding biomolecules. Transition-metal storage and transport. Metalloproteins. Electron-transfer proteins. Dioxygen transport and oxygen-atom-transfer reactions. The bioinorganic chemistry of Photosynthesis and Respiration. Hydrolytic reactions by metalloenzymes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Chemistry
courses.learning_outcomes: Bioinorganic chemistry is a frontier area in contemporary chemistry education and research. It spans the old boundary that previously divided the classical areas of chemistry and biology. The present multi-disciplinary elective course can give students an overview on this modern discipline. It also illustrates the use of basic chemical principles and conventional physical methods to tackle various problems in inorganic biochemistry.
courses.course_syllabus: An overview of bioinorganic chemistry. Principles of coordination chemistry related to bioinorganic research. Biomolecules: proteins, nucleic acids and other metal-binding biomolecules. Transition-metal storage and transport. Metalloproteins. Electron-transfer proteins. Dioxygen transport and oxygen-atom-transfer reactions. Photosynthesis. Respiration. Nitrogen fixation. Hydrolytic reactions by metalloenzymes.
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term evaluation in the form of questionnaires will be performed.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. S. J. Lippard and J. M. Berg, Principles of Bioinorganic Chemistry, University Science Books, California, 1994.

3. Bertini, H. B. Gray, S. J. Lippard and J. S. Valentine, Bioinorganic Chemistry, University Science Books, California, 1994.
4. J. J. R. Fraústo da Silva and R. J. P. Williams, The Biological Chemistry of the Elements - The Inorganic Chemistry of Life, Oxford University Press, Oxford, 2nd ed., 2001.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Organometallic Chemistry and Catalysis of d-Block Elements

meetings.instructor: Professor KWONG Fuk Yee

courses.description: Catalysis is a cutting-edge science and plays a central role in modern organic synthesis. Enjoying the modification of the ligand, the activity of the transition metal complex can be manipulated to fit specific catalysis. This course will give students an in-depth understanding of catalyst structures via organometallic and organic chemistry approaches, and how those catalysts (d-block transition metal complexes) can be applied in sustainable and complex chemical synthesis. The industrial applications of some tailor-made catalysts will also be discussed. In this course, student presentation of current frontier catalysis is required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MPhil-PhD Chemistry
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to acquire knowledge in the following areas,
1. Understanding of the concept of donor ligands’ electronic and steric properties.
2. Understanding the establishment of the catalyst by employing appropriate ligands.
3. The possible catalytic cycle/process and reaction mechanism of the catalysis.

courses.description: This course provides an overview of fundamental concepts and essential applications of supramolecular chemistry. This course covers two parts. The first part focuses on the fundamental concepts, including a brief history of supramolecular chemistry, characterization of supramolecular systems, noncovalent interactions and ion binding, templated synthesis and self-assembly as well as inclusion complexes. The second part focuses on the application of supramolecular chemistry, discussing selected supramolecular systems and introducing important examples of applying supramolecular chemistry in materials sciences and biology.

• Understand the basic concepts and principles of supramolecular chemistry based on the knowledge of organic chemistry
and physical chemistry.
• Apply these concepts and principles to explain the structures, properties and functions of supramolecules.
• Rationally design building blocks to construct supramolecular structures with certain functions.

courses.title: Advanced Chemical Biology

meetings.instructor: Professor XIA Jiang
Professor XIA Jiang
Professor XIA Jiang

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
meetings.instructor: Professor XIA Jiang

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT
meetings.instructor: Professor XIA Jiang

courses.description: This course offers postgraduate students who are interested in the research at the interface between chemistry and biology in-depth knowledge about chemical biology. The course has three modules. Module 1 covers the chemical structures, reactions, synthesis, and functions of biomolecules. The lecturer will first introduce four types of biomolecules, namely peptides and proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and nucleic acids to chemistry students, with a focus on their molecular structures, higher-order structures and organizations, and the organic reactions to synthesize or to transform these molecules in a synthetic laboratory or inside cells. The course will also focus on the functions that the structures and reactivities of the biomolecules encode. Enzymes, a special group of proteins will also be introduced to the audience, together with cofactors and coenzymes as one example of proteins possessing catalytic power. Module 2 will include current technologies developed in chemical biology, and selected research projects in this field, including literature review and guest lectures based on the knowledge delivered in the first two parts. Module 3 will be guest lectures in chemical biology. Through this course, students will be able to apply their chemistry knowledge to complicated biological molecules, to comprehend chemical biology research, and to identify/solve chemical biology problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil-PhD Chemistry
Not for students who have taken CHEM4200
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, the students should have:
1) acquired advanced knowledge of chemical biology
2) gained strong interests and motivation for chemical biology
3) been able to independently work on chemical biology problems
4) been able to plan and propose new chemical biology research projects

Module 2 will include current technologies developed in chemical biology, and selected research projects in this field, including literature review and guest lectures based on the knowledge delivered in the first two parts. Module 3 will be guest lectures in chemical biology. Through this course, students will be able to apply their chemistry knowledge to complicated biological molecules, to comprehend chemical biology research, and to identify/solve chemical biology problems.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1) Informal discussion with students on day-to-day basis
2) Regular communication with the TA. Ask the TA to collect feedback from the students.
3) Course questionnaire answered by every student after finishing all the lectures

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Mass Spectrometry of Biomolecules

meetings.instructor: Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic
Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic
Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic
Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic
Professor CHAN Tak Wah Dominic

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with the fundamental concepts and applications of mass spectrometry. It consists of several core modules including desorption/ionization techniques, ion activation methods, mass analysers and ion detectors. The use of mass spectrometry methods for structural elucidation of small organic molecules. Theory of unimolecular decomposition and simple mass spectral interpretation will be taught. Biological applications of mass spectrometry, including genomic, proteomic and glycomic applications, will also be taught. Through the guided literature reviews and presentations, postgraduate students will have a better understanding on the extended applications of mass spectrometry, including protein conformation analysis and mass spectrometry imaging.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Chemistry;Course Exclusion: CHEM4780
courses.learning_outcomes: The student should acquire a comprehensive understanding of the operation of mass spectrometry methods. This includes an understanding of the information that can be derived from a mass spectrometry analysis, the principles of various desorption / ionization methods, mass analysers, ion activation methods in mass spectrometry. The students should appreciate the complexity of proteomic, genomic and glycomic research and understand the role of mass spectrometry in these important disciplines of research. The students should also appreciate the potential of extended mass spectrometry applications through guided literature reviews and presentations.
courses.course_syllabus: This course consists of several core modules including ionization (desorption/ionization) techniques, ion activation methods, mass analysers and ion detectors. The use of mass spectrometry methods for structural elucidation of small organic. Theory of unimolecular decomposition and simple mass spectral interpretation will be taught. Biological applications of mass spectrometry, including genomic, proteomic and glycomic applications, will also be taught. Postgraduate students are required to undertake guided literature reviews and presentations, so that they will have a better understanding on the extended applications of mass spectrometry, including protein conformation analysis and mass spectrometry imaging.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Instrumental Analysis of Biomolecules
courses.description: This course reviews analytical methods to solve biological problems. It serves as a primer to the expanding field of bioanalysis. The topics covered by this course include: purification and separation, spectroscopic methods; eletrophoresis; mass spectroscopy; chromatography; NMR; analysis of nucleic acids; nucleic acid and protein sequencing; immunoanalysis, single molecule techniques; single cell analysis; biochips; etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Chemistry
courses.learning_outcomes:
The students will know the general available methods for biological problems
The students will know the basic principles behind the methods of analysing biological samples
The students will know the new development of biotechnologies.
courses.course_syllabus: This course reviews analytical methods to solve biological problems. It serves as a primer to the expanding field of bioanalysis. The topics covered by this course include: purification and separation, spectroscopic methods; eletrophoresis; mass spectroscopy; chromatography; NMR; analysis of nucleic acids; nucleic acid and protein sequencing; immunoanalysis, single molecule techniques; single cell analysis; biochips; etc.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Electrochemical Energy Conversion and Storage

meetings.instructor: Professor WANG Ying
Professor WANG Ying

courses.description: Electrochemistry is playing a more and more important role in the application of renewable energy. This course will cover the theory and practice of a broad spectrum in electrochemistry especially inelectrochemical energy storage and conversion systems. It will provide a brief introduction to the basic chemistry and physics concepts in electrochemistry. The further application in electrocatalysis,batteries, fuel cells, super capacitors and electrochemical synthesis will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil or PhD Chemistry
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to acquire knowledge in the following areas:
1. Learn the fundamental principles of electrochemistry and able to interpret experimental data
2. Develop an understanding for electrochemical process
3. Understand and be able to design and optimize electrochemical systems

It will provide a brief introduction to the basic chemistry and physics concepts in electrochemistry. The further application in electrocatalysis, batteries, fuel cells, super capacitors and electrochemical synthesis will also be introduced.

courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Computational Chemistry
courses.description: Review of statistical mechanics and quantum mechanics and their applications in modern computational chemistry simulations and brief overview of computational quantum chemistry. Some of the state-of-the-art methods will be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MPhil or PhD Chemistry
Not for students who have taken CHEM4710
courses.learning_outcomes:
• The students will learn how to deduce the macroscopic properties of matter from the properties of atoms and molecules through statistical mechanics, which offers a link between quantum mechanics and thermodynamics.

•They should develop hands-on skills to do modern computational chemistry calculations

• They should be able to understand the computational results now widely reported in the chemical literature.
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Review of statistical thermodynamics

(2) Introduction to Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics simulations

(3) Discussion of the secular equation, Hartree-Fock method, self-consistent field methods, density-functional theory

3) Cramer, C.J., Essentials of Computational Chemistry: Theories and Models, 2004
